title: forget jane eyre give students
story: Forget Jane Eyre - give students a chance by teaching books they can relate to"Trying to explain to young students who already feel like they have failed, why Jane Eyre is so important to them, is borderline abuse," says lecturer Stephen Tuffin Image: Publicity PictureopinionByStephen Tuffin:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec | commentsThis week, in a classroom near you, a baffled teacher will attempt to convince a disillusioned group of GCSE English students that learning why Jane Eyre doesn’t think Mr Rochester loves her, is going to make the world of dference to their futures. Why  No one knows. Or, at least, no one is willing to say. For as far back as anyone can remember, a stream of out-of-touch, often privately educated, Education Secretaries, have signed off on the idea that teaching student’s th century literature, at Level , is just what students need to secure them a decent job in the workplace. Students who don’t pass their GCSEs are forced to repeat what they’ve already failed at. Forced to engage with books written in a language they will never use. Trying to explain to young students who already feel like they have failed, why Jane Eyre is so important to them, is borderline abuse. At a time when young people are turning away from books and literature at an alarming rate, no one in government seems bothered or interested in providing students with something a little more relatable. Last week I had to face one such group. The futility and unfairness of it struck me mid lesson. I had no argument as to why they should engage with Dracula.  Why reading Stoker would be of use, interest, or benefit to them unless they had an express desire to go into further education. Which the vast majority don’t. Starting off a lesson with the words, ‘Today we are going to be looking at Dr Jekyll and Mr Hyde’ will mean within two minutes % of a GCSE class will have shut down. Do the powers that be think there is no other literature available to young people  Using contemporary texts by authors like Kit de Waal or Lisa McInerny, would at least give students and teachers a fighting chance. If educators were permitted to teach English using contemporary literature that told of the lives and challenges of iniduals who looked and sounded like the students they were teaching, on subjects like county lines, gangs and drugs, or any other aspect of st century teenage le, more students would engage. It’s what they are familiar with. What takes up much of their time. And using a language they use themselves exploring issues and situations they can identy with. A large section of the materials we currently use to teach our young students are entirely ineffective. In fact, they are worse than ineffective. Relying on these texts throws unnecessary, unhelpful barriers in the paths of students. It damages their already damaged faith in themselves and a system that is supposed to support, nurture, and encourage them. If you don’t believe me, ask them yourselves. @StephenTuffin is a lecturer in Swindon Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Conservative PartyEducationSchoolsPoliticsChristmas partyGCSEsRochester and Strood" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get UK politics insight with our free daily email briefing straight to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: mps give boris 30 days
story: Exclusive: MPs give Boris Johnson  days to come clean on Downing Street partiesSenior MPs, including a Tory former health minister, gave the Prime Minister  days to answer questions about the guest list for the party on December , and details of a party alleged to have taken place in his flat on November  Image: Tolga Akmen Lnp REX ShutterstockByMikey SmithWhitehall Correspondent:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec | commentsMPs have given Boris Johnson  days to come clean with details of lockdown-busting parties under his own roof. Senior MPs, including a Tory former health minister, gave the Prime Minister  days to answer questions about the guest list for the party on December , and details of a party alleged to have taken place in his flat on November . The cross-party group of MPs and peers - including Tory Dr Dan Poulter - today called on Cabinet Secretary Simon Case’s probe into the parties answer key questions within  days. Mr Case was last week tasked with investigating “the facts” of the party on December  in Number , details of which were first revealed by the Daily Mirror. The probe has since been extended to cover the party at the Department for Education, as well as a further gathering alleged to have taken place in the PM’s Downing Street flat on November . But Number  has resisted putting a timescale on his probe, with the PM only saying it would report back as quickly as possible. Today, in a letter coordinated by the All-Party Parliamentary Groupon Coronavirus, a cross-party group of MPs and Peers called on the PM to admit to “any other gatherings in Downing Street in contravention of Covid rules such as that alleged by Mr Cummings to have occurred on th November  ”And they demanded to know the guest list for the December  Christmas party, who organised and sanctioned it, and what knowledge of it the Prime Minister had at the time. It follows new polling, which suggests that % of people no longer trust the UK government to handle the nation’s pandemic response with % saying the scandal would negatively impact compliance with Covid rules. The polling, from from Best for Britain, the APPG’s Secretariat found % of  Tory voters thought it made people less likely to follow Covid restrictions - while % of Leave voters had also lost confidence in the government. Layla Moran MP, Chair of the All-Party Parliamentary Group on Coronavirus said: “We’ve heard first hand of the pain and loss people have endured during this pandemic. “To know that at the same time, those in Number  were partying and laughing about their rule-breaking, is absolutely sickening. “This investigation must be thorough. If the Prime Minister was aware of this party it is a resignation matter.” Naomi Smith, Chief Executive of Best for Britain said: “Our polling shows the real world dangers of a government that plays fast and loose with the trust of the British people. “This investigation cannot be a whitewash, with fewer people now expected to observe Covid guidelines, answering these questions is a matter of le and death.”  The letter in full Prime Minister,As the UK faces the new Omicron iant this winter, it has never been more important for the public to trust the UK Government’s response to the pandemic and observe all restrictions in place to save lives and protect the NHS. Therefore, the growing evidence supporting allegations of a social gathering at  Downing Street in contravention of Covid restrictions is deeply concerning.Your belated announcement of an internal investigation into this breach of Covid rules is welcome, but we remain concerned at the scope and the timeline of this investigation. For this reason we the undersigned ask you, to guarantee in writing that within the next  days, the investigation will provide answers to the following questions which are in the urgent public interest:Who attended the Downing Street party on th December  Who sanctioned and organised the event  Was the Prime Minister aware  And when did he become aware  Will the Prime Minister guarantee that all evidence is shared with the politan Police as soon as it becomes available  Were there any other gatherings in Downing Street in contravention of Covid rules such as that alleged by Mr Cummings to have occurred on th November  A Christmas party in Downing Street at a time when the public made enormous sacrices, including spending Christmas in isolation and far from sick and even dying relatives, would not only represent a flagrant breach of the rules, but a breach of the trust of the British people as well. At this crucial time in the pandemic, the public must have full trust in the UK Government’s ability to safeguard lives. It is vital that this investigation urgently restores public trust in the UK Government’s pandemic response and all public health measures in place. Signed,Layla Moran MP Dan Poulter MP Barbara Keeley MP Caroline Lucas MP Philippa Whitford MP Clive Lewis MP Ben Lake MP Liz Saville-Roberts MP Sir George Edward Howarth MP Baroness Brinton Lord Russell Lord Strasburger Baroness Masham Baroness Sheehan Christine Jardine MP Wendy Chamberlain MP Allan Dorrans MP Kim Johnson MP Hywel Williams Sarah Oley MP Jamie Stone MPRead MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Caroline Lucas MPBarbara Keeley MPJamie StoneKim JohnsonHywel WilliamsNaomi SmithBoris JohnsonNHSLabour PartyConservative Partypolitan PolicePensionsPoliticsChristmas partyCoronavirus" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get our daily coronavirus email newsletter with all the news you need to know direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: nazanin zaghari ratcliffe could home
story: Nazanin Zaghari-Ratclfe could be home for ChristmasUK hands £m to IranTehran has signalled it might accept the payment in Covid jabs and medicines, the charity workers husband Richard Ratclfe told the Sunday Mirror Image: Getty ImagesByNigel NelsonPolitical Editor:,  Dec | commentsCharity worker Nazanin Zaghari-Ratclfe could be home for Christmas -Britain hands over the £million it owes Iran. And Tehran signalled two weeks ago it might accept the payment in Covid jabs and medicines which would count as humanitarian aid. In an exclusive interview Nazanin’s husband Richard Ratclfe said: “All countries need vaccines. If the offer was worth more than £million Iran could be interested. “Andwe settled this debt Nazainin could be released the next day. It would be an amazing Christmas present for her to be home.” But as things stand Richard and daughter, Gabriella, , will spend their sixth Christmas without Nazanin despite his  day hunger strike outside the Foreign Office last month. Richard added: “Nazanin has been very blue these past few days, as the realisation has hit her that we are drting again. “But Gabriella has had a happy time decorating the tree and helping me put up lights. After the intensity of the hunger strike, it is also nice to have some good times.”  Nazanin, , has been detained in Iran since April,  and was sentenced to five years over spying charges. She now faces another one year jail term. Britain claims she is being held hostage with other dual nationals as the two countries wrangle over money. Ministers admit the cash is owed for battle tanks never delivered but keep coming up with dferent excuses not to pay it. In March Defence Secretary Ben Wallace said the UK’s refusal to cough up was “a stain on Britain’s honour”. Now he says the money can only be paid“a practicable and legally-viable means” can be found. Foreign Office minister Lord Zac Goldsmith said last month to pay would be ransom money. He added: “Payment of any money becomes payment for a hostage. That is not in our current, medium or long-term interests.” Richard said: “His comments were legally illiterate and irresponsible for the message it sent to Iran. “Ministers cannot throw out words like “hostage” and “ransom” when they just want to deflect Parliamentary scrutiny. “My fear is that the debt is also leverage for the UK side - using it to push Iran into the nuclear deal or something  - and Nazanin has become a bargaining chip for both sides.” Middle East minister James Cleverly refuses to talk about negotiations saying he “will not comment further as discussions are ongoing.” Foreign Secretary Liz Truss had meetings with Iranian Foreign Minister Hossein Amir-Abdollahian on th November and another with his deputy Bagheri Kani three days later without any resolution.  In  Iran ordered , Chieftain battle tanks and  repair vehicles costing £million from Britain. Only  tanks were delivered before the  Iranian revolution overthrew the Shah and pitched the country into the hands of Islamic clerics and Britain banned arms sales. When new Iranian leader Ayatollah Khomeini asked for a £million refund to make up for the missing weaponry Britain refused to hand it over. Yet in  the international court in The Hague ordered Britain to repay the money which is still sitting in an independent trust in the UK. Iran now wants £million in interest which Britain will not pay either. Britain has argued the money cannot be repaid because Iran is under UN sanctions - yet that did not stop America coughing up a similar sum to release four American prisoners in . And former Foreign Secretary Jeremy Hunt said: “We are a country that pays its debts.”Mrs Zaghari-Ratclfe’s family have said she was repeatedly told that her arrest was linked with the debt that the UK owes. Richard has now been on two hunger strikes - the first two years ago outside London’s Iranian Embassy - but he is not about to embark on a third. He said: “They put a real strain on the family, as well as on my body. So none planned for a while, and hopefully none needed.” Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON NHSMiddle EastUnited NationsForeign OfficeJames CleverlyAyatollah Ruhollah KhomeiniZac GoldsmithJeremy HuntNazanin Zaghari-RatclfeLiz TrussPrisonsIranChristmas partyDebtHandsTribunals" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get UK politics insight with our free daily email briefing straight to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: new covid rules week work
story: All the new Covid rules this week as work-from-home order kicks in tomorrowBoris Johnson shted to Plan B as scientists predict the new Omicron iant will overtake Delta as the most dominant strain of coronavirus within daysMake the most of Christmas shopping and other festivities by taking precautionsByRachel WearmouthSenior Political Correspondent:,  Dec | commentsCovid restrictions are being ramped up after scientists discovered the new Omicron iant is much more transmissible and spreading rapidly across the UK.Prime Minister Boris Johnson announced on Wednesday that England would move to the Governmentaposs Plan B measures.Epidemiologists fear the iant could cause , deaths by April and that the NHS could be overwhelmed as Omicron looks set to overtake Delta as the dominant iant within days.So, what do the latest Covid curbs mean for you  Hereaposs the latest.Working from home People in England are being urged to work from home where possible from Monday. This is aimed at reducing contacts.The furlough scheme has not ed, however, as no businesses are being shut down at this stage. The advice is to work from home aposwhere you canapos.Face masksNew rules brought into force on Friday mean that anyone aged  or over must wear a face mask to enter a wide range of indoor venues. These include places such as cinemas, casinos and bowling alleys. The full list: community centres , youth centres, members clubs and social clubs libraries and public reading rooms shops public transport polling stations and premises used for the counting of votes places of worship crematoria and burial ground chapels visitor attractions and entertainment venuespublic areas in hotels and hostels indoor areas of sports stadiumsPubs, bars and nightclubs are exempt. There is also an exemption for singing, which applies to, for example, congregations and choirs. Technically, a person could avoid wearing a face mask by singing, but the Government has warned protestors attempting to abuse this rule will be stoped.Care homes  From Wednesday, there will be a new restriction on care home visits.Care home residents will be asked to pick three people to visit and one essential care worker.Covid passports From Wednesday, England could be facing the introduction of mandatory covid passes proving your vaccination status to enter some venues, including nightclubs.So a punter could have proof of double jabbed status or, under the new pass rules, a text message or email from the NHS showing a lateral flow result to get into a venue.Firms failing to check Covid passes properly may be fined £, and up to £, for repeat offences.But Boris Johnson is facing a major backlash to the plan as Tory backbenchers look set to vote against the plan. The PM may get the changes though parliament with Labour support but given he is under major pressure over the Christmas parties plan, the rules could be watered down.What about Christmas So far, there are no limits on travel, household mixing and meeting groups of people.Downing Street has also rejected calls to put new restrictions on hospitality venues, so your Christmas party can still go ahead.What about a aposPlan Capos  Officially, there is no Plan C. The Prime Ministeraposs official spokesman said on Friday there were no plans to go beyond what weaposve set out already. But Omicron could change things, and Health Secretary Sajid Javid is under pressure to bring in more stringent measures before Christmas.Further measures could include hospitality check-ins, tougher isolation rules, face masks in all indoor venues and further vaccine passport rules.Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Plan BBoris JohnsonNHSAppsThe economyPoliticsCoronavirus" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get UK politics insight with our free daily email briefing straight to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. news politics shock-poll-finds--brits-"Boris Johnson declines to repeat official denial about staff party at No ByAletha AduPolitical Correspondent:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec | commentsBoris Johnson’s efforts to tackle the new Coronavirus iant are at risk as a Mirror survey has found three in four Brits are less likely to follow fresh Covid restrictions following revelations of lockdown parties in Downing Street. The UK recorded its highest number of Covid infections since January  today and UK scientists warned millions could catch the new strain before the New Year as it will become the dominant iant in the UK by mid-December. The Survation poll for the Mirror reveals % of people are less likely to follow Covid rulesGovernment officials have broken them. The survey of , Brits online found % believe Government officials did break the rules at the peak of the second wave, with % stating the incidents should be investigated by the police. And % of Conservative voters who backed Boris Johnson in the last General Election believe the Tories think itaposs one rule for them and another for everyone .The poll comes after Professor Chris Whitty said he fears Brits will not accept new lockdown restrictions after enduring almost two years of the pandemic. Speaking to a  at the Local Government Association he added: “My greatest worry at the moment is that people…we need to do something more muscular at some point, whether it’s for the current new iant or at some later stage, can we still take people with us ”  The Office for National Statisticsinfection survey found  in  people had Covid in England, in the week ending December . This equates to around , people. On Friday face masks were made mandatory in most indoor spaces including cinemas, theatres, churches and galleries.And from Monday those who can work from home are advised to do so, and on Wednesday the NHS Covid Passwill become mandatory for entry into nightclubs and other large gatherings.The PM’s spokesman slapped down rumours of a Covid ‘Plan C’ or a ‘Plan B plus’ being prepared for the New Year just in case the plan B measures did not curb the new iant. Plan B measures are set to be introduced next week, with MPs set to vote on the measures in the Commons on Tuesday. But at least  Tory MPs are set to rebel and vote against the introduction of tighter Covid restrictions, with many furious with Mr Johnson’s handling of Downing Street party revelations.  Former Tory chief whip Mark Harper said the PMaposs authority has been diminished by the Owen Paterson sleaze row and the alleged Downing Street party. He told the Commons on Wednesday: “Why should people listen to the Prime Minister’s instructions to follow the rules when people inside Number  Downing Street don’t do so ”And renowned rebel Steve Baker told the Mirror he hoped Labour would vote against the measures.But shadow Health Secretary Wes Streeting slammed rumours of Labour voting against plan B restrictions in order to defeat the PM.He told BBC ’s Radio  Today programme “public health has always come first for the Labour Party during the pandemic. Despite the trouble the Government finds themselves in, public health will still come before party politics”. Sir Keir Starmer said the booster programme should have been ramped up weeks ago. “The Government pooh-poohed that it’s now doing it but again, as ever, too late, he added.The Survation study put Labour on a six-point lead over the Conservatives, which suggests voters have lost faith in Mr Johnsonaposs handling of the pandemic following the party scandal. Since the Mirror first revealed parties were held at the Prime Ministeraposs Number  flat in the run up to Christmas last year, the PM is now facing accusations of seven separate parties and drinks doaposs held across Westminster in November and December last year. Cabinet Secretary Simon Case is currently investigating three dates on which bashes were said to have been held in breach of lockdown rules. They are, a No leaving do on November  at which the PM spoke a No Christmas party on December  and a Department for Education bash on December . Downing Street has cancelled its Christmas party this year blaming the increase in workload for the cancelled plans. The Prime Ministeraposs spokesman said: I think weaposve made it clear since the latest situation with Omicron, obviously thataposs taking up a great deal of time at the moment. He added: Thereaposs no plans for [a party] in Number .On November , sources told the Mirror people gathered for drinks in Boris and Carrie Johnsonaposs flat above  Downing Street. And on the same day, farewell drinks were held in number s round table room - the night Dominic Cummings quit. Two weeks later on November , sources claim  to  people crammed into a room at Number  to say goodbye to top aide Cleo Watson, an ally of Cummings. Former Education Secretary Gavin Williamson has admitted to holding a canapes reception for his top team on December . Four days later people working on the London mayoral campaign for candidate Shaun Bailey held their own ‘raucous’ party. And on December  the Mirror broke the story about the Number  Christmas Party. ITV News reported on Thursday that Jack Doyle, who was then deputy director of communications at No , addressed up to  people at a Christmas gathering said to have been held on December .He offered to resign but the PM turned it down. A Number  spokesperson said Ed Oldfield is still in his position and the PM is still confident with his position, despite accepting Allegra Stratton’s resignation. title: top lawyer not convinced boris
story: Top lawyer not convinced Boris Johnson Xmas quiz was exempt from Covid lawsAdam Wagner,Barrister and Visiting Professor of Law at Goldsmiths University of London, walks the Sunday Mirror through what a police officer who happened upon the No Christmas Quiz might have done Image: SIPA USA PA ImagesAnalysisByAdam Wagner:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec | commentsIt’s useful to think what a police officer who happened upon the No  Christmas quiz in December  would have done. Let’s assume the officer found groups of ying sizes, including one room with - people, participating in a Christmas quiz, with alcohol, which led to drinks later and mingling between offices. On  December , London was in Tier . Under paragraph  of Schedule  to the “All Tiers” regulations, no person could participate in a gathering indoors of two or more people. The officer would have considered possible exceptions. The first relevant one is a “permitted organised gathering”, under paragraph . But that could only workpeople participated alone or in household groups. That doesn’t seem to apply here. The second is that the gathering was “reasonably necessary for work” under paragraph . Maybe the civil servants would say that they needed the quiz for morale, or had to stay at work to run the government.  The officer might think: well, what is “reasonably necessary” for an office is a bit subjective. But the government told us exactly what they thought was “reasonably necessary for work” – their own guidance at the time said “you must not have a work Christmas lunch or party, where that is a primarily social activity”. So that seems to exclude the work exception. The final question is whether No.  was somehow exempt from the Covid regulations. Lawyers have been debating this. I’m not convinced. I think the “crown property” exemption was about government buildings, not people. And I doubt that people could say they were doing their duties as crown servants and therefore exemptthey were doing things which the government had advised everyone not to do – and which broke the law. As for the Prime Minister – he appears to have been taking part in a social gathering indoors of more than one person, so may well have breached the regulations too. title: tough covid curbs needed next
story: Tough Covid curbs needed by next week to save NHS from , patients a dayThe NHS could be overrun by , people a day being admitted with Covid unless new curbs are brought in by next week to stop the spread of the Omicron iant, it is reportedNHS staff wear PPE as they treat a coronavirus patient Image: Adam Gerrard Sunday MirrorByTim HanlonNews Reporter:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec | comments The UK government has been told that tougher Covid restrictions are needed as soon as next week to prevent hospitalisations from passing last winteraposs peak it is reported.Public health officials are advising that eventhe rapidly spreading Omicron iant causes less serious illness than Delta, it could lead to , people being admitted to NHS hospitals per day.Health Secretary Sajid Javid was given a presentation from the UK Health Security Agencythis week where he was told that “stringent action” would be needed on or before December the iant’s doubling time stays at . days,reported.Prof Neil Ferguson, from Imperial College London, whose data was key to the UK going into lockdown in March , told the newspaper that projections suggest Omicron could “very substantially overwhelm the NHS, getting up to peak levels of admissions of , people per day”. He predicted that the figure could be reached “sometime in January”the iant is resistant to existing protection and it has a similar severity to Delta - which is not yet known.  “Even the best-case scenarios involve several-fold more admissions per day than we’re getting at the moment – we are at about  right now,” he added. It comes as scientists say that Omicron could become the dominant iant by as soon as next week. And the government is currently looking at putting in stricter restrictions, it is reported. Daily Covid- cases have now reached their highest level in almost a year and the UKHSA predicted that,current trends continue, the UK will exceed one million infections by the end of the month. The UKHSA has also found that the AstraZeneca and Pfizer-BioNTech vaccines provided “much lower” levels of protection against symptomatic infection with Omicron compared to Delta.Cabinet minister Michael Gove warned of a “deeply concerning situation” after holding a Cobra meeting on Friday afternoon to discuss the latest data and the co-ordinated response across the four nations.The government said there had been a further , lab-confirmed Covid- cases in the UK and the last time a higher daily figure was reported was on January , when , cases were recorded. An additional  confirmed cases of the Omicron iant have been reported across the UK, bringing the total number to ,. Dr Mary Ramsay, head of immunisation at the UKHSA, said early data indicates that “a few months after the second jab, there is a greater risk of catching the Omicron iant compared to Delta strain”. She added: “The data suggest this risk is signicantly reduced following a booster vaccine, so I urge everyone to take up their booster when eligible.” Gove said the Omicron iant is doubling every two to three days in England “and possibly even faster in Scotland”. He added that % of reported cases in London are the new iant, and warned that evidence suggests Omicron is “more likely” than past Covid iants to “potentially” lead to hospital admissions among the fully vaccinated.  Scotland’s First Minister Nicola Sturgeon has warned of the possibility of a “tsunami of infections” from the new iant – and said she could not rule out more restrictions north of the border as a result.But so far Boris Johnson has “no plans” to go further with measures in England, amid claims that he is considering a Plan C with tougher restrictions.Now under Plan B, people are required to wear masks in more indoor spaces including museums, galleries and community centres. There will be ato working from home guidance from Monday, and mandatory Covid passports for large venues from Wednesday.The new regulations will be put to a debate and vote in the Commons next week – and with Labour ’s support they are certain to be approved despite the prospect of a large Conservative revolt.Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON NHSOmicron iantCoronavirus" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get our daily coronavirus email newsletter with all the news you need to know direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: treasury staff held lockdown drinks
story: Treasury staff held lockdown drinks party to celebrate Rishi Sunaks spending review"It wasn’t a formal party but perhaps in hindsight it wasn’t the most sensible thing to do,” a source saidMr Sunak is not thought to have been at the party to celebrate his Spending Review Image: AFP via Getty ImagesByMikey SmithWhitehall Correspondent:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec | commentsTreasury staff held a lockdown drinks party to celebrate Rishi Sunakaposs spending review, it has been revealed. Some staff who worked on the  autumn spending review had office drinks while England was under lockdown restrictions.It comes as Boris Johnson battles mounting revelations of rule-breaking festivities in Downing Street in the run-up to last Christmas.The Times reported that around two dozen civil servants were present for the drinks on November , . A Treasury spokesman said: A number of HMT staff came into the office to work on the Spending Review . We have been made aware that a small number of staff had impromptu drinks around their desks after the event. The Treasury did not organise an in-person departmental party last Christmas.  “They’d all been working really hard,” a source told the Times. “They had to be in the office anyway that day. It wasn’t a formal party but perhaps in hindsight it wasn’t the most sensible thing to do.” At the time non-essential shops, leisure and entertainment venues were closed as well as pubs, bars and restaurants, and people were urged to stay at home except for limited reasons including workit could not be done from home.The Times said Chancellor Rishi Sunak was not at the event and that it is understood he was not aware of it at the time.Downing Street said it has cancelled any plans to hold a Christmas party this year. It came as Boris Johnsonaposs ex-aide Dominic Cummings said there are lots of photos of parties in No  that will inevitably get out.Mr Cummings dismissed defences from the Prime Ministeraposs allies that he would not have known about celebrations going on under his roof amid signs Mr Johnsonaposs popularity is slumping.  Government chief whip Mark Spencer insisted Downing Street staff were not drinking alcohol and partying during Covid restrictions after it emerged the Prime Ministeraposs press chief addressed staff at one event last Christmas.No  said Mr Johnson retained full confidence in Jack Doyle to serve as communications director despite ITV reporting he addressed up to  people and made a speech at one party on December .Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON JohnsonsThe TreasuryThe TimesPlan BJack DoyleMark SpencerBoris JohnsonCivil servantsPoliticsChristmas party" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get UK politics insight with our free daily email briefing straight to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: arthur labinjo hughes treated despicably
story: Arthur Labinjo-Hughes was treated despicably - we must unite to stop it happening againSix-year-old Arthur Labinjo-Hughes death is a reminder that society as a whole should be preventing future such acts of cruelty and injustice, writes Katie PiperArthur Labinjo-Hughes, six, was killed by stepmum Emma Tustin Image: PAopinionByKatie Piper:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec | commentsNormallythere’s a topic I’m really passionate about, I will post about it on Instagram.But with the horric case of Arthur Labinjo-Hughes, who was killed by his father and stepmother, I just couldn’t find the words to convey how I felt.The way he was treated was absolutely despicable – and when you see the worst of humanity like this it can make you question a lot of things in le. Collectively, from the public to the Govern­ment, we need to do every­thing we can to prevent any future such acts of cruelty and injustice. Social workers are passionate about change, and it’s a really tough job – it is unfair to single out iniduals for the death of a child when we need to be looking at society as a whole.  I also really welcome the Attorney General’s announcement of a sentence review in the case of little Arthur’s killers. It highlights a wider issue of the need for tougher sentences on serious crimes. As I have personally experienced this with sentences for the perpetrators of acid attacks, I feel strongly that there should be a minimum term for serious crimes such as these – with no exceptions. And we can only hope harsher sentences act as a deterrent to those who would otherwise commit such acts.  Serious crimes are trivialisedsentencing is not tough – it’s vital the justice system places a true value on human le and dignity. Seeing football stadiums erupt into applause for Arthur in a display of public unity last weekend really touched my heart. As the public, we have the luxury of hindsight. But by addressing these issues head-on now, we can prevent another tragic case such as little Arthur’s from happening again. news uk-news banksy-launches-shirt-range-raise-"Banksy fans queue for limited edition T-shirts in BristolByChiara FiorilloNews ReporterRod MinchinBen Bloch:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec Artist Banksy has designed and launched a T-shirt range to raise funds for four people accused of criminal damage over the toppling of a statue in Bristol. The defendants will go on trial on Monday after being accused of pulling down the statue of th century slave trader Edward Colston during a Black Lives Matter protest on June  last year.The anonymous artist announced on Instagram he created a limited edition grey souvenir T-shirt to mark the occasion.The T-shirts, which went on sale in Bristol today, have a picture of Colstonaposs empty plinth with a rope hanging off, with debris and a discarded sign nearby and BRISTOL written above. Banksy said in the social media post that proceeds from the sale will be given to the four people facing trial next week in the city accused of criminal damage, so they can go for a pint. The Bristol-based artist said sales would be limited to one per person and each T-shirt would cost £ plus VAT. Banksy wrote in the caption: Next week the four people charged with pulling down Colston’s statue in Bristol are going on trial. Iaposve made some souvenir shirts to mark the occasion. Available today th December from ious outlets in the city .  Rhian Graham, , Milo Ponsford, , Jake Skuse, , and Sage Willoughby, , face trial at Bristol Crown Court from Monday. The bronze memorial to the slave merchant was pulled down during a protest in June last year, before being dumped in Bristol Harbour and later recovered by Bristol City Council. Charges allege that the four defendants, without lawful excuse, jointly and with others, damaged the statue, a listed monument belonging to the city council.  The defendants are accused of committing the offence intending to destroy or damage such property or being reckless as to whether such property would be destroyed or damaged. Further details on the sale of T-shirts created by Banksy were announced this morning at am on the Ujima Radio breakfast show, a local station. They will be sold in the following locations:Frontline Video in St Paulaposs Hakuna Matata on Stapleton Road in Easton That Thing on Stokes Croft Friendly Records in Bedminster Rough Trade RecordsBristol Live reports that people have been queuing this morning to get hold of the T-shirts.A seller on Ebay already posted the T-shirt on the website with a price of £,.  Today, there will also be a protest organised by campaigners in support of the four defendants. They are also planning to hold a peaceful rally outside Bristol Crown Court on the first day of the trial of the four people accused of criminal damage. The trial is expected to last up to eight days.Follow MirrorFacebookTwitterMORE ON BanksyCriminal damageCrime" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: bride says dream wedding been
story: Bride-to-be says dream wedding has been ruined by scaffolding erected around churchSusan Forde and her partner have been left distraught after scaffolding was erected around the Church of St Mary Magdelene inLeicestershire, ruining the couple’s picturesque locationSusan Forde is due to marry her partner Rob Image: LeicesterLiveByLee GarrettGraeme Murray:,  Dec | commentsA bride-to-be has claimed her picturesque dream wedding has been ruined by scaffolding erected around the church. Susan Forde, will marry partner, Rob, in just over a weekaposs time and had been looking forward to the big day after it being repeatedly pushed back because of the pandemic. But she and her partner have been left distraught after scaffolding was erected around the Church of St Mary Magdelene in Melton, Leicestershire, ruining the couple’s picturesque location.“I never thought I would get married, but I met Rob and that all changed,” Susan told Leicestershire Live.“I’m a believer in God and want to get married in a church. I have been to Stapleford Hall a lot over the last  years and just fell in love with it. This was the only place I could imagine getting married at.  “When you’ve invested so much time and emotion into this over so many years, it’s upsetting that my dream has been ruined.” The appearance of the scaffolding and associated works came at short notice and has left the couple from Oadby angry at those in charge of the church and Stapleford Hall. After investing thousands in their wedding and delaying it multiple times, they say they’ve been badly let down. Rob said: “We had paid so much over the years, money which has gone into the upkeep of the place and this is what we get in   “It’s disgraceful.”  “I’m angry they’ve behaved like this,” said Susan. “Why couldn’t they hold back until after our wedding  It would have been just a matter of days, that’s all.” The Churches Conservation Trust, which owns the Church of St Mary Magdalene, said the scaffolding was needed out of urgency.A spokesman said: “As a charity, we have been fortunate to receive a grant from the Government’s Heritage Stimulus Fund to carry out urgent repair work to the tower pinnacles and parapets of the west tower, which has become heavily fractured due to weather erosion and unstable,“This funding opportunity is time-limited, and we are obliged to carry out the repair works as soon as possible. “We are very sorry for the distress caused by the appearance of scaffolding at the church. We realise the huge impact this must have had on the iniduals involved and for this, we are very sorry.” Stapleford Hall was keen to point out how urgent the works were. A spokesman added: “As the work was deemed as essential emergency repairs, Stapleford Park is pleased that this amazing church is being safeguarded for the future. “We sympathise greatly for the couple and can confirm that no element of the wedding ceremony or reception has been affected due to the nature of the works to the exterior of the church.” With so much changing so quickly, keep on top of what is happening with the Mirroraposs news updates by email. Delivered straight to your inbox, our daily coronavirus briefing will keep you informed of what is happening with Covid, lockdown, the vaccination rollout and the impact on how we live.here. “We have also offered suitable alternative ceremony locations for the couple.” Susan and Rob turned down this alternate offer and will go ahead with the ceremony on December  even though it wasn’t how they had imagined. It’s a major part of our day,” said Susan. “There’s a picture of the church on our order of service. We’ve got people coming from Ireland and Leeds for the day and all of them want to see the church.” “This isn’t going to be the same. It’s so disappointing.” “We’ve been treated shoddily and are not happy,” said Rob. “We believe more could have been done to avoid this happening.” The Churches Trust said they did everything they could. A spokesman said “We were in touch with the Stapleford Estate as soon as we were aware of the works needing to take place at the church to enable them to liaise with the couples and we offered options of rescheduling or refunds. “In the meantime, our contractors are doing what they can to make the church as presentable as possible despite the scaffolding.” Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON LoveMarriageWeddings" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: christmas day weather forecasters predict
story: Christmas Day weather: Forecasters predict temperatures will plummet in festive weekThe south of England and Wales could have a white holiday season as temperatures plummet on Christmas Eve. Frost and fog will sweep across the country on the big day.Snow in South Lanarkshire earlier this weekByLeonie Chao-Fong:,  Dec | commentsBritons are braced for a chilly Christmas as forecasters predict frost to grip the country. During the festive week, temperatures in the south of England and Wales will plummet on Christmas Eve, just in time. While frost and fog will sweep across the country on Christmas Day.People in the North West will have slightly milder weather on December . In the last week of the year, the weather will be settled yet cold for many, The Sun reports.The Met Office said: Temperatures are expected to be near normal for most, but milder in the northwest and perhaps turning rather cold in the south in time for Christmas.  It is likely to remain settled for the final week of , with an increasing risk of frost and fog for Christmas and New Year. While itaposs too early to tellBritain will see a blanket of snow during the holidays - forecasters can predict this accurately five days prior - snow is more likely between January and March than in December. On average, snow or sleet is expected to fall an average . days in December, compared to . days in January. While snow was recorded last Christmas, only four percent of British weather stations recorded snow lying on the ground.There has only been a widespread covering of snow on the ground - where more than % of stations in the UK reported snow on the ground at  am - four times since —in , ,  and , the Met Office reports. Before the cold weather, Britons will have unseasonably warm weather, will mild temperatures at the start of next week. title: couple quoted 16k transform ugly
story: Couple quoted £k to transform ugly garden do it themselves and save £kElizabeth Astin, , and her husband bought furniture and decorations from discount stores Amazon, BM and The Range then carried out the physical work themselves to cut costsThe couple say they saved £, Image: LatestDealsByLeonie Chao-Fong:,  Dec | commentsA couple quoted £, to transform their “barren and ugly’ garden saved a whopping £, by doing most of the project themselves. Elizabeth Astin, , and her husband, sourced materials, furniture and bargain decorations from the likes of Amazon, BM and The Range instead of paying professionals to do the legwork. The couple, from Birmingham, sourced wooden sleepers for their builder saving them £,.Their nephew fitted the electrics and they built a relaxing zen area using leftover supplies, , BirminghamLive reports. Elizabeth sourced bargain decorations and furniture from Amazon, BM and The Range.  She told money-saving community LatestDeals: We moved into our house as a new building  years ago. When we bought it, the agent told us that there was no back garden. What they meant was that there was a lower patio area with a huge retaining wall and a sloping upper area that was north facing. Not very attractive at all. Still, it stood us in good stead over the years. Our girls had water fights, we bought numerous bouncy castles, water slides and paddling pools and my husband and his dad made a decking for the adults to chill. We always wanted to improve it but it was for the kids. While they were young, it was more important for them to have a safe place to play. Now they are grown up, we wanted to finally tackle the garden and improve it. The first step was planning. It was dficult with the garden being on a slope. We realised we needed at least two levels or terraced areas to be able to have somewhere to entertain and relax. The back garden gets sun at the top of the garden all day long, she said, so the couple worked around it to make sure they maximised the sunshine.She added: Before starting on the makeover, I had spent a lot of time browsing the Facebook group ‘DIY on a budget gardens’.I learned a great deal and got lots of inspiration from group members. We were always mindful to try and keep costs down without compromising on quality and our dreams.  We saved up for all of this including replacing the iron railings with a lovely glass fence. It was a big project. The existing decking was built by my husband and father in law when we moved in two decades ago. This had to be pulled down and the areas levelled. We had a beautul clematis that sadly had to be pulled down too and that was done by my husband - it took him two days to do it. It was a complete makeover. We also had to pull down and replace an ugly iron fence on top of the large retaining wall. The couple paid a builder to do the landscaping, build the patios and replace concrete slabs with Indian stone, which took up the main budget. Elizabeth said: We had to get someone in to build the glass and steel fence as well as do parts of the project ourselves due to the nature of the makeover and the retaining wall. We had to ensure the wall could hold the new patio areas so we needed professional help. The building work was £k but we saved money by having the electrics fitted by our nephew who is an electrician. Also, we managed to reduce the price by using wooden railway sleepers rather than building retaining walls. The builder provided all the materials. We had an original quote for £k from another builder so by having the sleepers we saved approximately £k. The glass fence was £, and once that was installed, my husband used the leftover Indian stone and sleepers from the builder to create a little zen area. He built a bench and a space to put a relaxing water feature on. We also reused the old gray slabs from the original patio and laid them in the front garden, to build a little seating area. Part of this area included tub chairs we already had from Aldi, which we had bought the year before for £. I bought furnishings such as cushions and decorations from Amazon and BM. I probably spent around £ on these, again trying to source the best value for money.  The day bed was from The Range. I searched for the best price and got it for around £. The same bed on other websites were between £ and £ so I basically got it half price. I also wanted to arrange the plants to suit the new makeover. Most of them were already there before - I just replanted them. We did, however, buy a few more from a local garden center. They were very cheap - probably no more than £ for all of them. Now the project is finally done, it’s our safe haven. We managed to save thousands by combining professional work with DIY and my husband created an amazing little zen area that was previously barren. The garden is a sanctuary for us to relax in now. The only thing which didn’t go to plan was the installation of the furniture, as it took a while for it to arrive. If we had to do this project again we would order it well in advance as we only received the dining set this week. It’s now in the garage waiting for next year!’ Tom Church, Co-Founder of LatestDeals said: Elizabeth and her husband have managed to create a stunning garden that no doubt increases the value of their property, after waiting nearly two decades to complete the makeover. With dficult areas, sometimes getting a professional in is best - but as Elizabeth has proven, sourcing budget supplies and doing parts of the overall makeover yourself can save you thousands of pounds. I hope this garden lasts them many years to come. title: covid booster available 30 year
story: Covid booster available for -year-olds from Monday amid Omicron deaths warningThe booster programme is being rolled out to younger age groups in a bid to tackle soaring coronavirus infections and fears the Omicron iant could cause a new surge in JanuaryThe booster programme will provide millions of people across the country with a third vaccine dose to increase protection Image: Andy Commins   Daily MirrorByCatherine WylieSam Rkaina:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec | commentsPeople aged  and over will be able to book a Covid- booster jab from Monday in England. The national booking system will open to everyone aged  to  so that they can arrange to get the top-up jab three months on from their second dose.The extension of the NHS vaccine programme comes as scientists advising the Government warned that tougher Covid restrictions may be needed to prevent the Omicron iant causing anywhere between , to , deaths in England over the next five months.NHS England said the rollout has been accelerated in the face of Omicron, with data from UKHSA suggesting that booster doses give good protection against the new iant. People can make their booking two months on from their second dose - a month in advance of becoming eligible to receive the jab.  There are around . million people aged  to , and . million of those are eligible from Monday. Dr Emily Lawson, head of the NHS Covid- vaccination programme, said: Following the updated guidance from the JCVI, which shortened the interval between second and booster doses, NHS staff are redoubling their efforts to protect the public from the virus. The NHS vaccination programme, the biggest and most successful in health service history, will from tomorrow offer top-up jabs to everyone aged  and over three months from their second jab. With the emergence of the new iant and the rising case numbers, there has never been a more important time to get boosted. So, when itaposs your turn, come forward and book in. The vaccine programme has been designed and delivered by NHS staff but it could not have been rolled out so quickly without the support of our fabulous volunteers. So,you are interested in helping us, we have roles available - from marshalling car parks as a volunteer or taking on a paid role in admin or as a vaccinator, please do look at the opportunities available. You would be helping us to save lives. Health and Social Care Secretary Sajid Javid said: The Covid- booster programme is accelerating rapidly and more than  million people in the UK have already received their top-up, securing vital protection ahead of Christmas.This is our national mission - the most recent data shows boosters are the essential defence against Omicron and we are doing everything in our power to get jabs into arms as quickly as possible. We are now expanding the offer to over-s - so please come forward as quickly as possible to get boosted and help our country get ahead in this race with the iant. Experts from the London School of Hygiene  Tropical Medicine , who also sit on the Scientic Pandemic Influenza Group on Modellingor the Scientic Advisory Group for Emergencies , used experimental data to look at how Omicron may transmit as the country heads into , and predicted a large wave of infections in January. On Friday, analysis by the UK Health Security Agencyfound that the AstraZeneca and Pfizer vaccines provided much lower levels of protection against symptomatic infection with Omicron compared with Delta. But the UKHSA said a booster dose gives around % to % protection against symptomatic infection with Omicron, as it urged people to have their boosters. title: diy couple transform plain kitchen
story: DIY couple transform plain kitchen into rustic space using £. IKEA bargainsRachel Green, , and her partner Max Butler, , didnt rate their plain cupboards and drab black worktop, so decided to completely transform it on the cheap by sourcing materials from Poundland, Ikea and BQA couple transformed their plain kitchen into a modern, minimalist cooking spaceByRyan FaheyNews Reporter:,  Dec | comments A bargain-hunting couple used smart DIY hacks and clever purchases to completely transform their kitchen into a rustic cooking space. Rachel Green, , and Max Butler, , slashed costs of revamping their brown cupboards and black worktop by hunting for bargains on BQ, Ikea and Facebook Marketplace. Taking it on as a lockdown project, the couple also scrolled through Pinterest to get their inspiration. During lockdown when we were house searching we had a lot more time on our hands, they told bargain site LatestDeals. So I spent hours on Instagram and Pinterest saving pictures of my favourite ideas and creating a mood board for each room.The kitchen had plain brown cupboards and black worktops, so we decided to create more of a monochrome feel with marble effect countertops and matching accessories. We did the whole project on a budget by sourcing items from BQ, IKEA and Facebook Marketplace. They found some of the items they needed at Homebase, including a roller set for £. and two tins of Maison Deco Refresh paint to cover the worktops, cupboards and splash-back. But to jazz it up, they painted their fittings gold. They said: To add a special touch we decided to make all the handles on the wardrobes and drawers gold. We did this by removing them all and spray painting them with a can from Amazon. It cost just £.. They protected the worktops with two rolls of self-adhesive film that they bought at BQ for £. They added: One addition we wanted for the kitchen was some shelves. One of our friends gave us the idea so we could get some cupboard space back, as well as have the ability to rescue some of our nicer ceramic pieces from the back of the cupboards. I’d also seen the idea of a shelf pantry all over Instagram and wanted to recreate it for myself. To find the materials, we searched Facebook Marketplace for people selling scaffolding wood for cheap and we managed to get them for £ a board.  Then we just sanded them slightly, keeping some of the roughness, as that was the look we were going for. We got the brackets off Etsy, and these turned out to be one of the most expensive purchases. We went for some rustic handcrafted brackets made from reclaimed timber and they were £. And they added to the rustic, homely feel by placing items, like an Asda casserole dish for £ and Poundland jars, on top of the wood. They said: Some of the other jars came from IKEA for the pasta, and they were £. each. While we were in IKEA we picked up some faux foliage for the shelves and the tops of the cupboards for around £, and a gold rail for additional wall storage for £. They used sugar soap to wash down the surfaces before sanding them down. By taking off the draw handles, they could spray them gold without causing a mess in the kitchen. They slapped two coats of paint on the skirting boards, ceiling and cupboards. They said: Overall it was very easy to do, it was just time consuming waiting for the paint to dry and hard to get to some of the cupboards to paint them. If we had to do it again, we would take the doors off to complete the job. We had tried to avoid doing this as we thought we might struggle to get them back on. However, it made it a lot harder to paint without getting inside the cupboards too. news uk-news first-omicron-symptom-seen--"Omicron iant will dominate Delta before Christmas says expertByDaniel SmithLeonie Chao-Fong:,  Dec | commentsScientists say a common symptom reported by people who fall ill with Omicron is a dry cough accompanied by a ‘scratchy throat’. Anecdotal reports follow a large outbreak of the Covid iant in the UK.The Centers for Disease Control and Preventionhas been part of a concerted effort to understand Omicron after it was classied as a iant of concern by the World Health Organisation last month, WalesOnline reports. The strain spreads far faster than previous iants, although so far few hospitalisations have been reported.In itsMorbidity and Mortality Weekly Report , researchers at the CDC have put forward a preliminary symptom profile for Omicron.The report states that a cough is the most common symptom, afflicting  percent of those infected. The authors of the CDC wrote: “Many of the first reported cases of Omicron iant infection appear to be mild, although as with all iants, a lag exists between infection and more severe outcomes.” “Symptoms would be expected to be milder in vaccinated persons and those with previous SARS-CoV- infection than in unvaccinated persons.  “Characteristics of the cases described in this report might also not be generalisable because case findings might be associated with inidual characteristics. The details of the report draw on the cases of  infections attributed to the Omicron strains. Only seven percent of subjects presented with ‘asymptomatic’ infection or ‘unknown’ symptoms, with  percent of cases deemed symptomatic. “Evenmost infections are mild, a highly transmissible iant could result in enough cases to overwhelm health systems,” wrote the authors where in the report. The report lists cough , fatigueand congestion or runny noseas the three most common symptoms. Shortness of breath , diarrhoeaand loss of taste or smellall featured at the bottom of the CDC’s list. news uk-news football-fans-march-memory-tragic-"March to St Andrews for Arthur Labinjo-HughesByKelly-Ann MillsReporterZoe Chamberlain:,  Dec | commentsAround a thousand football fans took to the streets today in memory of little Arthur Labinjo-Hughes who was killed by his dad and stepmum. Chanting aposWe love you Arthur, we doapos, the caring Birmingham City supporters united in their mission to make sure the six-year-old was remembered by all. Fans got together at the Bullring Tavern from noon, then began their march at .pm, laying a wreath and other tributes along the .-mile route to the match against Cardf City. Posters and hoardings were put up along the route from Digbeth to St Andrewaposs saying Gone But Never to be Forgotten.  There were blue and white balloons and blue smoke poured into the air in a touching celebration of a le cut way too short. Cardf City fans clapped Blues fans as they arrived at St Andrewaposs, where floral tributes and teddies were laid for the little boy. Arthur was tragically murdered by his stepmother Emma Tustin, who routinely beat, isolated, starved and force fed him salt laced meals.  He was also made to stand for up to  hours a day at their home. She is serving at least  years in jail while his father, Thomas Hughes, , was handed a -year term for manslaughter. Birmingham City Football Club produced a special match day programme in memory of young Arthur. For every copy sold on December , the club will donate £ to a local children’s charity.  Fans and well-wishers also took to social media posting their messages of love for the little boy after a heartbreaking video was shared in court where Arthur could be heard sobbing aposnobody loves me.apos Birmingham City supporters posted photos of the hoardings and posters lining the streets of the route, saying: A Little tribute to Arthur. Lot of frantic effort but well worth it. GONE BUT NEVER TO BE FORGOTTEN. Brilliant work by those that made this possible.  Birmingham City bosses have also renamed their family zone Arthuraposs Area, which has gone down well with fans. Chris O’Brien tweeted: “Well done Blues. The Peoples Club. Arthur will always be part of the Blues family. Wish he could see all this love he has had and will have.” Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Football fans" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: geminid meteor shower light up
story: Geminid meteor shower to light up sky with celestial display of shooting stars on MondayThe stellar display is expected to peak some time during the night of December  and will be visible into the early morning of December This Geminid meteor shower from  make for some spectacular sights Image: PAByNina Massey:,  Dec | commentsSkygazers will be treated to a celestial display of shooting stars on Monday, as the Geminid meteor shower illuminates the night skies. The display, which s every December, is expected to peak some time during the night of December  and will be visible into the early morning of December . Meteors are pieces of debris that enter Earthaposs atmosphere at speeds of up to km per second, vaporising and causing the streaks of light we call meteors. Geminids are very bright, moderately fast, and are unusual in being multi-coloured. They are mainly white, some yellow and a few green, red and blue, partly caused by the presence of traces of metals like sodium and calcium - the same elements that are used to make fireworks colourful.  The shower is known to produce more than  meteors an hour at its peak, although light pollution and other factors mean that in reality the actual number visible is far fewer. The source of the shooting stars is a stream of debris left behind by the asteroid  Phaethon, making this one of the only major showers not to originate from a comet.  Skygazers will be able to see the display with the naked eye so there is no need for binoculars or a telescope. It is best not to look directly at the radiant as this can limit the number of meteors people can see. Instead, people should look just to the side in a dark area of sky for a better chance of seeing the display. title: inside queens mail sack 300
story: Exclusive: Inside Queens mail sack - with  letters a day about cats, bus stops and teaReaders share their stories of writing to the Queen and getting a reply, from a request to send a cat a birthday card to an appeal to overhaul bus stops to save a hairdoThe Queen receives sackloads of mail Image: Press AssociationByJulie McCaffrey:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec | commentsBuckingham Palace is looking for a first-class royal servant to answer sackloads of mail sent to the Queen. Her Majesty receives around  daily letters from her fans and it is little wonder she needs a hand to reply to each one. The new assistant correspondence officer will help ensure the monarch’s mail receives a prompt and proper response befitting of the royal crest. As the job advertisement says, many of the posted letters are unique. From a request to send a cat a birthday card, an appeal to overhaul bus stops to save a hairdo and adorable children’s drawings, readers share their stories of writing to the Queen and getting a reply. Would you like to come for tea  Jane Frances’s six-year-old daughter Neve was travelling from Merseyside to London in April  to see a theatre show and thought she’d invite the Queen out for tea. Jane says: “I didn’t want to crush Neve’s dream by not posting the letter, even though I never thought we’d get a reply in a million years.  “Neve was ecstatic when she received a reply from Buckingham Palace. Her Majesty respectfully declined Neve’s invitation, which is perhaps inevitable since the day we were in London was Prince William’s wedding day!” I painted a picture of your favourite horse Shane Hagan felt so much affection for the Queen she felt compelled to send her a painting of her horse Sanction. The -year-old, from York, says she “absolutely loves” the monarch and wanted to give her something back after all she has done for our nation. She adds: “I took up painting after corrective eye surgery and, because I know the Queen loves horses, I painted one of her favourites and sent it along with a Christmas card. “I don’t think anyone imagines they’ll receive a letter back from the most famous woman in the world. “So when I received one, thanking me and encouraging me to continue painting, I was chuffed to bits. Now I’m a full-time artist.” Can you cover bus shelters  My mum is fussy about her hair In , nine-year-old Emma Parsons was so annoyed by mum Jeanette’s hairdo being ruined by rain as they stood at a bus stop she decided to do something. “I thought the Queen could sort this out,” she says. “So once I’d dried out at home, I wrote to Her Majesty to ask for help. I askedshe could put seats and roofs on all the bus stops, but to cover our one first. “My dad, Vince, said I’d never get a reply. Two weeks later none of us could believe our eyes when I received a letter from Buckingham Palace.”  The Queen’s lady-in-waiting explained “it is not within the Queen’s control”, but Emma, now , says: “Soon afterwards the bus stop, outside Cardf Castle, was modernised and I have taken full credit for that.” Civil servant Emma adds: “My parents weren’t sentimental, but that letter was kept and I still have it. My grandchildren are very impressed.” My daughter charmed the Queen with her story about the young Princess Elizabeth A teacher was so impressed by Lottie Trewick’s story of the Queen and Princess Margaret playing in the grounds of Buckingham Palace that she sent it to Her Majesty. And -year-old Lottie was thrilled to receive a reply.  Lottie’s mum Karen, from Winchester, Hants, says: “Lottie wrote the story during the Queen’s Diamond Jubilee in  and there was a lot of excitement about the Royal Family. “And she was doubly excited to receive a response.  “The letter says: ‘Her Majesty was pleased to see your charming tale about a mighty oak tree which, in your story, became a great fortress for Princess Elizabeth and Princess Margaret’. “We framed the letter.” Will you send my cat a th birthday card  When Rachel Thomas, of Barmouth in North Wales, heard that the Queen sends cards to those celebrating their th birthday she was keen to remind her not to forget a special centenarian: her cat. Rachel, now , says: “When I was , I realised my -year-old cat Sindy was  in cat years. “So I wrote to Her Majesty asking for a card for my cat. “Her reply said that the Queen can’t send a card to a cat.  “But I was so proud to get a letter from the Queen’s lady-in-waiting that I went around all the classes in my school to show off the letter I had received.” Iaposm worried about koalas Fearing for the impact on wildle during last year’s Australian bushfires, six-year-old Esme Robinson wrote to the Queen to express her concern. Shortly after sending it, the nation was plunged into lockdown and the Queen stayed at Windsor Castle.  Esme, of Herts, lost hope of receiving a reply to her letter sent to Buckingham Palace. A few weeks later she was stunned to receive a special letter franked with the royal stamp. Mum Suzi says: “It was a great moment of excitement at a time when we all had to stay at home.” Get well soon Nine-year-old Summer Wise was off school with Covid in October when she heard the Queen had spent the night in hospital. She wrote to wish her a speedy recovery. Her mum Natasha, of North West London, says: “Summer wrote in her neatest writing and decorated the envelope with stickers and drew a picture of Windsor Castle. Summer told Her Majesty she was also ill and asked her lots of questions.  “She was astounded when she received her reply from Windsor Castle containing a leaflet all about the Queen so she could find the answers to her questions. “We’ll keep the royal reply for ever.” Here’s a chocolate medal  some bunting Three-year-old India Grainger sent Her Majesty a chocolate medal and some bunting to celebrate her diamond jubilee in . Her mum, Hester, from Reading, Berks, says: “India dictated her letter to me and was very specic about what she wanted me to write. She was incredibly excited when we posted it but doubly so to receive a letter back.  “She said she was touched that India had given her a chocolate medal and some flags. And India was over the moon. “The framed letter hangs in our bathroom.” You are the best queen in the whole wide world Keen to bring a smile to the poorly Queen’s face, seven-year-old Chloe Elmer drew her gold and purple crown, her hats and a giant love heart. And in a letter adorned with more hearts and “I love you”, Chloe, of Basingstoke, Hants, wrote: “Dear your majesty, I hope you are fellingbetter. You are the best queen in the wholwide world.” Mum Elizabeth said: “Chloe really wanted Her Majesty to know she was in her thoughts. She even researched the Queen’s favourite colour for the hats. “A few weeks ago we had a letter from the Queen’s lady-in-waiting, thanking Chloe. She was completely shocked and had the biggest smile ever. She’s so proud to know Her Majesty took the time from running the country to write. “Chloe’s letter is a frame on display as a treasure.” We have a race horse you bred Knowing the Queen is passionate about horses, Louise Rowe wrote to give Her Majesty an update one she had bought from her in August . Louise, , from Dorking, Surrey, says: “I wanted to let the Queen know Otago, a horse she had bred, was really happy, doing well and making us proud.  He has won at Epsom twice and I said he had a home for le with us once his career ended. I was thrilled to receive a reply – she wished me well with Otago. The Queen’s letter and card will be treasured for ever.” We are related Student Cameron Holmes wrote to the Queen two years ago to tell Her Majesty: “We’re related.” Cameron, , from Malton, North Yorks, says: “A relative traced our family tree all the way back to the s and discovered that my th great grandfather was King James V of Scotland. I felt I had to let her know.  “Maybe I shouldn’t have been so surprised to receive a reply from Buckingham Palace – we are family, after all.” The letter, which sends Cameron’s family good wishes and includes a genealogical chart of the Kings and Queens of England, is now framed in Cameron’s home. Happy birthday Barnaby Hocking, seven, from Paignton, Devon, made the Queen a nd birthday card while doing art with his dad Dean.  Barnaby’s mum Victoria says: “The day the reply came, with the Buckingham Palace stamp, the postman ran up our drive – he was almost more excited than we were. “We didn’t expect to hear back. For the letter to be so personal means an awful lot. Barnaby was so proud he took his letter to school.” Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON The QueenBuckingham PalaceRoyal FamilyCivil servantsChristmas cards" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get our daily royal round-up direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: inside santa school hopefuls can
story: Exclusive: Inside Santa School where hopefuls can earn £ a day - but training is snow jokeA Santa shortage caused by Covid and Brexit means Father Christmas stand-ins can earn £ a day - Dan Hall went to Santa School to learn the tricks of the tradeDan Hall with his Santa School certicate after Father Christmas training Image: © Steve BainbridgeByDan HallFeatures Writer:,  Dec | commentsKids across the country have just  more doors to open on advent calendars before Father Christmas’ magical arrival. But what does it take to step into the big man’s boots A staff shortage at grottos caused by Covid and Brexit means wannabe Santas can earn as much as £ a day. Sounds tempting, right But is it as easy to turn into Father Christmas as it sounds  Here’s how I got on spending a day at a Santa School... In the corner of a London yoga studio is a decorated Christmas tree, wrapped presents, and an ­ominously vacant chair. That’s because the studio is hosting Santa School, where ­volunteers will be put through their boot-clad paces to seethey have what it takes to be Saint Nick. It might sound like a laugh but, as I found out, the training is snow joke.  Leading our course is Ministry of Fun founder James Lovell, a Santa specialist who has been teaching wannabes for the likes of Selfridges since . His first lesson for me is that there is a lot more to the job than you might think. And he has high standards, believing every interaction a child has with Santa must be sensational. He says: “I remember when I met Father Christmas for the first time. It was amazing. I’ve still got the pencil case he gave me. It was at Beales ­department store in Bournemouth. “It has to be an experience that children remember for ever. So I thought, ‘In ­order to make sure that anybody meeting Santa has a magical time, we need to look at what it’s all about’.”  That means giving careful consideration to how Santa looks, how he speaks, and how he should handle tricky questions from kids. After a brief history lesson on the origins of St Nicholas, it’s time to get into his iconic gear. Like Christmas presents, Santa suits available to buy y in quality. The one James wears when he plays Father Christmas features a super-realistic £, beard. Whereas the costume I’m putting on is a little more cheap and cheerful, and features an acrylic wig that makes me look like the drummer from Slade. And while fake Santa bellies are available, I simply stuff a cushion under my coat. Given that it’s a chilly December day, the heating at the studio is on full whack and that makes me hotter than a freshly roasted turkey.  But just like the great man himself, nothing will stop me pressing on – evenI do spare a thought for all the Santas who’ve spent long days in shopping centre grottos in the full itchy garb. It’s then time to practise a few ho ho hos – the trick is to deliver it more as a laugh than a statement – before having a go at role-playing in a grotto. As they say, the proof is in the Christmas pudding. How one handles kids is what makes the dference between an absolute cracker of a Santa and a tree-mendously bad Father Christmas impersonator. James, who acts as a kid in the role-play, tells me before we start: “I’m quite brutal. If people aren’t very good I will tell them. “People have to know. You can’t just laugh it off. You wouldn’t do that with a child sitting opposite you.” No pressure then. I start OK but within a couple of questions I unravel like a poorly knitted Christmas jumper. “Did you get my letter ” James asks me, playing a young boy. I reply: “Yes I did, I enjoyed it very much and put it on the wall above my... magic fireplace.”  My improv skills aren’t quite as strong as I’d imagined. Five more excruciating minutes follow, where, among other ­embarrassments, I fail to recall the names of Santa’s reindeer. James’s verdict: “There was lots that was good about that, though you did go down a bit of a conversational cul-de-sac. “The fireplace… Don’t know what happened there.” He adds: “But you were jolly, so that was good.” My own verdict was that, despite my best efforts, I was ho ho hopeless. The training was put on by network site Nextdoor, which arranged for  volunteers to learn how to play Santa for communities. They acted after finding that % of people are at risk of not ­seeing Father Christmas this year, with % of the country not having a dedicated Santa Claus in their area. Roisin O’Neill, head of community UK at Nextdoor, says: “The reason we’re doing this is we ­believe every neighbourhood ­deserves a visit from Santa.” Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Father ChristmasChristmasSunday People" data-immediate"data-immediate"Join the Secret Elves for celebration inspiration - and brilliant gt ideas and reviewsSpread the cheer!Invalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you.
